question:
An ecommerce company uses Amazon Route 53 as its DNS provider. The company hosts its website on premises and in the AWS Cloud. The company's on-premises data center is near the us-west-1 Region. The company uses the eu-central-1 Region to host the website. The company wants to minimize load time for the website as much as possible.

Which solution will meet these requirements?

options.A: Set up a geolocation routing policy. Send the traffic that is near us-west-1 to the on-premises data center. Send the traffic that is near eu-central-1 to eu-central-1.
options.B: Set up a simple routing policy that routes all traffic that is near eu-central-1 to eu-central-1 and routes all traffic that is near the on-premises datacenter to the on-premises data center.
options.C: Set up a latency routing policy. Associate the policy with us-west-1.
options.D: Set up a weighted routing policy. Split the traffic evenly between eu-central-1 and the on-premises data center.

explanation: Geolocation routing directs traffic based on user location, sending users to the nearest endpoint. Users near US West Coast go to on-premises (near us-west-1), and European users go to eu-central-1, minimizing load times based on geographic proximity.
